did.unittitle: Manuscripts
"Yours very truly, N. P. Willis"
Quotation beginning, "If there is a feature of the human soul . . ."
Poem, " Impromptu"

scopecontent.p: [Tipped to paper with engraving of Ashland; marked Page 5.]

did.unittitle: Essay, "Jottings-down about the time of the Queen's Marriage"
Poem beginning, "My Mother! in thy prayer tonight . . ."
Poem beginning, "Now I have seen a kadji . . ."

scopecontent.p: [Includes ANS on verso to "Dear Sir" stating that the three verses he sent him are from his poem " The Lady Jane. "]

did.unittitle: Poem, " Thou Hereafter"

scopecontent.p: [Includes attached autograph; page is marked 3.]

did.unittitle: Poem, " Toujours Perdrix"

scopecontent.p: [From " Lady Jane. "]

did.unittitle: Poem beginning, "We met like rain-drops in the air . . ."

scopecontent.p: [Includes attached magazine drawing.]

did.unittitle: Letters
Nathaniel Parker Willis, England, to Mrs. Skinner

scopecontent.p: [Says he is pleased and flattered that she will present him at Lady Arundel's hall; recalls meeting her and her celebrated friend [Jane] Porter, a writer.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, London, to Messrs. Harper, New York

scopecontent.p: [Gives the Harper Co.instructions for the republishing of Pencillings; says the volumes will be dedicated to John B. Van Schaick. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, New York, to [Benjamin Franklin] Butler, Washington

scopecontent.p: [Says he is writing a book on American scenery to be published in England; asks for his help in getting the duty reduced; makes an argument why the whole book should not be subject to duty.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Old Charlton, Kent, to Mary Russell Mitford, Reading, England

scopecontent.p: [Says he has dedicated " Tortesa the Usurer" to her without her permission; says that this play and " Bianca Visconti Or The Heart Overtasked" have been so successful in Americathat he could buy a beautiful farm on the Susquehanna; sends book by Miss Sedgwick; talks about a book on travel in the making; encourages her to give up all other writing in favor of play writing where she is so very successful; talks about a planned trip to the south of Europe; urges her to join him and his wife.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Dublin, Ireland, to James Henry Hackett, Dublin

scopecontent.p: [Says he has been to the theater in Dublintwice to see Hackett perform his Yankee characters; invites him to dine at the Rev. Dr. Wall's , where he will meet the Lord Mayor of Dublinand others.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, New York, to Asa Hutchinson, New York

scopecontent.p: [Writes on behalf of a committee; mentions plans to give a free concert in New Yorkin honor of General Morris who has done so much for the country; asks him to participate; includes signatures of Dr. Alban Goldsmithand George Endicott. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, New York, to Abraham Hart, Carey & Hart, Philadelphia

scopecontent.p: [Explains why certain poems of his do not lend themselves to drawings; says they express feelings and are not of a descriptive nature, but that others are suitable for Mr. Lentze's pencil; mentions a book review.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Glenmary, England, to Rev. John Gorham Palfrey, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Discusses poetry that Willis promises to write for North American Review, sooner or later; mentions the high regard The North American Reviewenjoys in England. ]

did.unittitle: N. Willis, Cambridge, to "My Dear Sir"

scopecontent.p: [Complains that his lectures and meetings at Cambridgetake up all his time; mentions correspondent's work on a collection of Egyptian and Moorish plates belonging to Willis.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Highland Terrace, to Elizabeth Oakes Smith

scopecontent.p: [States that the Home Journalis always at her service.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Benson John Lossing, [ New York]

scopecontent.p: [Discusses some of his verses and the imminent birth of a daughter or son.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto George Pope Morris, [ Philadelphiaor New York]

scopecontent.p: [Discusses his recovery from illness, the publication of a piece in Morris' periodical, and painter [Lawrence] who "makes everybody look as they will look in Heaven."]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Epes Sargent, [ Boston]

scopecontent.p: [Discusses " Lysteria, " a dramatic poem; asks him who the author is; finds fault with an engraving of himself; wants Mr. Smith, the engraver, to change the eye area, the under lip, thicken the hair, etc.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to [Catherine Ann Ware] Warfield, [ Natchez]

scopecontent.p: [Discusses a book she wants to sell to publisher; says he is so disgusted with negotiating bargains with publishers that he has somebody else do it for him; sympathizes with her; says that The Home Journalwill do its best to ensure the book's success once it is published.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to James T. Fields

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for a chronicle of his visit, which was glowingly written about by Mrs. Harry Otis; talks about his Dedication Hymn and a letter from Dr. [Beattie], London, regarding it; hopes that Fields will "insert" it somewhere; describes a June morning.] (tipped in book, The Bryant Festival at the Century)

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to the Rev. E. Peabody

scopecontent.p: [Praises [Ephraim?] Peabody's wonderful writing, which is worth collecting; talks about his "brain-troubles"; says he has been advised by his physician to stop writing for several years or risk sudden death; chooses to take the risk rather than endure intellectual idleness; speaks about The Home Journal; says that all entries do not meet his high standards; invites the Peabody family to visit his house.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild>, to George Pope Morris, [ New York]

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for gossiping letter and asks for more of the same; reports on a novel in progress; mentions the frozen Susquehanna river. ] (A portion of the letter has been cut out because it obtained an obscene sentence.)

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to James T. Fields, New Yorkor Boston

scopecontent.p: [Pleads with him to "give the world your likeness," namely, allow bearer of letter, [Mathew] Brady, to take his picture.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild>, to Nathaniel Ingersoll Bowditch

scopecontent.p: [Says he is pleased to have received Bowditch's book Suffolk Surnames; states that excerpts from it have already appeared in The Home Journal, but he will speak of it again.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Thomas Raynesford Lounsbury, [ Yale University]

scopecontent.p: [Says he cannot help him with inquiries; offers "boyish" compositions he wrote in 1825, his Sophmore year; hopes they might be of help.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to [Theodore Sedgwick] Fay, [ New York]

scopecontent.p: [Says that letter will be presented to Fay by New Yorklawyer James [B.] Thayer, who is to sail to Europe; states that Thayer would like to introduce George Greento Fay.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, New Bedford, to H. Prescott, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Regrets not to have met Prescott, a person of "sovereign genius," during his stay in Boston. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to [John Williamson] Palmer, Baltimore

scopecontent.p: [Discusses piece by Mrs. Palmer on Shakespeare; regrets not being able to use it in The Home Journal. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Almont Barnes, Carthage, New York

scopecontent.p: [Discusses Barnes' poem [" The Eagle's Feather"] which Willis will probably publish.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to [John Williamson] Palmer, [ Baltimore]

scopecontent.p: [Requests autograph; sends one of the stanzas Palmer speaks of.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to [John Williamson] Palmer, [ Baltimore]

scopecontent.p: [Sends autograph of poem " Saturday afternoon"; acknowledges receipt of two books.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Osmond Tiffany, [ Baltimore]

scopecontent.p: [Acknowledges the receipt of a [book]; says he will look for Tiffany's name in review articles.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, [ Washington], to James T. Fields, Paris, France

scopecontent.p: [Says he would like Fields to go to the English Embassy and ask for the address of Lady Jenkins, one of the world's most charming women, widow of Sir Richard Jenkins, formerly president of the East India Company. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Anne Lynch Botta

scopecontent.p: [Says that his household has been overwhelmed with company, "all up-hillers," and his wife is now sick in bed; says he cannot comply with Botta's request to write his own obituary; sends her some scraps which he has gathered over the years, which seem to him discriminating or noteworthy; speaks of his wife's great affection for Botta.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to John Williamson Palmer, [ Baltimore]

scopecontent.p: [Says he is not able to help him with his inquiry; suggests approaching Henry Tuckermanwith the matter.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Miss Faulkner

scopecontent.p: [Printed form-letter; tells her in a very polite way that he does not feel like writing her a personal letter.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Frank W. Ballard

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for a flattering letter.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to George Pope Morris, [ New York]

scopecontent.p: [Sends him what he believes is his best "Scripture Poem" ever; asks him to take it to Bonner.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, [ Washington], to Mrs. Charles Eames, [ Washington]

scopecontent.p: [Responds to her claim that he lives in a halo and that she does not know what his face looks like anymore by sending his "likeness"; walks past her home 6 times a day on his way to and from Willard's for his meals; looks up to her window for a smile, in vain.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto one of his children

scopecontent.p: [Says he is not feeling well and waits for "Mamma"; sends a letter from young Stace; signs letter, "your affectionate papa."]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to George Pope Morris

scopecontent.p: [Discusses Morris' health, Willis' family matters, The Home Journal, increase in advertising; mentions Epes Sargent. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, [ New York], to Teresa Viele, [ New York]

scopecontent.p: [Says that an attack of vertigo kept him from writing her; sends early copies from [ Home Journal]; encourages her to write more; mentions visitors to his home, including Mrs. Henry Hills, Mrs. Henry Grinnell, and Anne Lynch Botta. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Woolrich, England, to Sir Charles

scopecontent.p: [Discusses difficulties with Captain Frederick Marryatand an avoided duel, the serious illness of his wife, and his tentative plans to return to America, depending on the recovery of his wife; mentions Jane Porter's presence and his indebtedness to Sir Charles.]

did.unittitle: Cornelia Grinnell Willis, Idlewild, to Fitz-Green Halleck

scopecontent.p: [Writes for her husband who injured his hand in a fall; says they look forward to Halleck's visit to Idlewild. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Glenmary, to R. [Londen]

scopecontent.p: [Expresses condolences after the death of Londen's wife; includes ALS, Londen to Willis, on verso, acknowledging condolence letter.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto "My dear Haight"

scopecontent.p: [Discusses a misplaced letter, and how hard Willis is working; comments on mutual acquaintances.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, New York, to Charles S. Ogden, Philadelphia

scopecontent.p: [Says he is overburdened by work; decides to send him this preprinted letter; tells him in a autograph note that he does not have Poe's autograph.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Thomas Bailey Aldrich

scopecontent.p: [Sends requested letter having to do with publishing business.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Glenmary, to George Virtue, England

scopecontent.p: [Sends fifth portion of " Ireland"; says it should reach Englandby boat December 1; mentions [James] Grant. ]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to James Parton
Nathaniel Parker Willis, New York, to George Pope Morris, New York

scopecontent.p: [Discusses Home Journalcopies for Madame Calderon de la Barca, wife of Spanish minister; says copies are to be sent to an address on Long Island; reports on his improving health.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Idlewild, to Samuel Bulkley Ruggles

scopecontent.p: [Urges him to send forgotten other half of a poem by [Regis De Trobriand]; says he would love to publish it; declines trip to Nantucketas he has too many houseguests at the moment; urges him to visit again in the fall, to join Mrs. Hills and Mrs. Otis and have a "time."]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Home Journal, to Abraham Hart, Carey & Hart, Publishers, Philadelphia

scopecontent.p: [Discusses business; asks them to date and sign an enclosed document.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willis, New York, to Abraham Hart, Carey & Hart, Philadelphia

scopecontent.p: [Discusses business, a new edition of his poems; agrees to their terms, which are the same ones they give Longfellow, but wants to revise and refine his poems before publication; asks for $300 advance; encloses drawing of one of his poems; says same young artist will do any number of such drawings, cheap.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto [ T. C. Hausard]

scopecontent.p: [Discusses printing of " Tortesa the Usurer" and "Bianca."]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto James T. Fields, Boston

scopecontent.p: [Introduces Patterson, who will deliver the letter by hand, to Fields; says Patterson is the editor of the [Anglo-American] and "one of our choicest spirits, as well as best critics."]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto Ph. H. Brown, Esq.

scopecontent.p: [Responds to request for autograph.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto [ R. Gilmor]

scopecontent.p: [Promises to visit him to renew their acquaintance; remembers his kindness in former years.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto Anne Lynch Botta, [ New York]

scopecontent.p: [Sends check for 3 tickets she sent him; compliments her on last night's dancing.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto [Mrs. Butler]

scopecontent.p: [Sends her promised verses, possibly AMs poem beginning, "My Mother! in thy prayer tonight . . ."; says he will send lines on the President's grandchild at a better moment.]

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Parker Willisto "Dear Sir"

scopecontent.p: [Informs him that he is ready to receive him tonight between seven and eight.]

scopecontent.p: [Include AN on verso, Willis to one of his sons.]

scopecontent.p: [Includes attached AMsS poem beginning, "We met like rain-drops . . ."]
